channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Ford Poaches Senior Executive, Doug Field, from Apple's Car Project
item.description: And now for some news Apple definitely won’t send any invites about: Ford has poached the executive who reportedly led Apple’s secretive car project to become its own “chief advanced technology and embedded systems officer.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Batteries Are a Solid Opportunity for EVs
item.description: Ford and BMW have partnered with another solid-state battery startup, Solid Power.  Why it matters: EV batteries are a key arena as automakers compete to make cheaper and more durable electric and hybrid vehicles. Besides Toyota, other automakers have also made bids on advanced battery tech: Volkswagen invested in the Bill Gates-backed battery startup QuantumScape.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: New Apple iPhones to be Announced Next Week
item.description: Apple could also use the event to announce new AirPods, Apple Watches, and streaming content or devices for Apple TV+. Yesterday, the company sent out invites for its annual (and still virtual) launch event where it’ll announce new products.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 8
item.description: Women accounted for a record 59.5% of college students at the end of 2020–2021 school year, while men made up just 40.5%. (The Guardian) Read: The disastrous voyage of Satoshi, the world’s first cryptocurrency cruise ship.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Toyota Spends $13.6 Billion to Develop Electric Vehicle Battery Technology
item.description: Ford and BMW have partnered with another solid-state battery startup, Solid Power.  Why it matters: EV batteries are a key arena as automakers compete to make cheaper and more durable electric and hybrid vehicles. Besides Toyota, other automakers have also made bids on advanced battery tech: Volkswagen invested in the Bill Gates-backed battery startup QuantumScape.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Dealmaking, from M&A to IPOs, on Track to Break Records in 2021
item.description: IPOs2021 has been the busiest year for IPOs since 2000, according to Axios. 279 companies have IPO’d in the US this year, easily beating last year’s total of 218. But get ready for a deluge of announcements once bankers head back to their monitors this fall, including potential IPOs from Chobani, Discord, Reddit, Instacart, and Rivian. because it’s hard to get much work done in Santorini, August was its typical slow self for dealmaking. The dealmaking surge is one the main reasons Goldman is the best performing stock in the Dow this year, up 56%.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Death and Life of NYC’s Financial District
item.description: The backstory: On the eve of 9/11, the Financial District (FiDi), was a finance hub.  In the years since, many banks left the neighborhood, primarily for Midtown. the Covid-19 pandemic has presented fresh challenges for FiDi, with a major downturn in the number of commuters and tourists hurting local businesses. The neighborhood’s residential population has more than doubled since 2000, according to a WSJ analysis.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Study Shows Automated Résumé Scanner Mistakenly Rejects Millions of Viable Job Candidates
item.description: Some of those keywords might not seem obvious. While there are 10 million job openings in the US that employers desperately want to fill, automated hiring systems are excluding viable candidates.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 7
item.description: (Incunabula) This thread explains.  Read: How did ham and cheese lead to hardcover books? “It may have been the financial promotion with the single biggest audience reach in history,” Randell said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Longer Waits, Safer Planes: How 9/11 Changed Air Travel
item.description: After hijackers commandeered four planes the morning of September 11, 2001, the US revamped its process for airport security screening to prevent similar attacks. Airlines took a hit: Airline revenue for domestic US flights fell by $10 billion/year from 2001–2006. Only in November 2001 did the government create the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to handle security at airports.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Weibo, China’s version of Twitter, Suspends 21+ K-Pop Fan Accounts
item.description: Later that day, Weibo said it would ban a number of other celebrity accounts in an effort to “purify” its platform. When Americans were all winding down from their second Saturday, Weibo—China’s version of Twitter—suspended at least 21 fan accounts for K-pop bands like BTS and Blackpink. – MM
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: El Salvador’s Grand Bitcoin Experiment
item.description: Welcome to El Salvador, where the pupusas are warm and the bitcoin is tender. Bukele also thinks that, by being an early adopter, the country could become a destination for foreign investment in bitcoin mining.  One-quarter of El Salvador’s GDP comes from remittances—money sent back to the country from people working abroad. Today, the Central American nation will become the first sovereign state to make bitcoin “legal tender,” meaning it’s now an official currency alongside the US dollar.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Longer Waits, Safer Planes: How 9/11 Changed Air Travel
item.description: After hijackers commandeered four planes the morning of September 11, 2001, the US revamped its process for airport security screening to prevent similar attacks. Airlines struggled to recover: Airline revenue for domestic US flights fell by $10 billion/year from 2001–2006. Only in November 2001 did the government create the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to handle security at airports.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: El Salvador’s Grand Bitcoin Experiment
item.description: Welcome to El Salvador, where the pupusas are warm and the bitcoin is tender.  Like all experiments, this one could backfireDespite all the buzz around digital currencies, bitcoin hasn’t been used as one at scale before.  And because bitcoin by definition skirts traditional financial institutions that promote stability, the International Monetary Fund is concerned that El Salvador’s adoption of the crypto could create serious risks for the country’s economy.  One-quarter of El Salvador’s GDP comes from remittances—money sent back to the country from people working abroad.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: But some of those keywords might not seem obvious. While there are 10 million job openings in the US that employers desperately want to fill, the flawed automated hiring systems are excluding viable candidates.

item.title: The Week Ahead: September 6
item.description: 9/11 anniversary: As we mentioned earlier, Saturday will mark 20 years since the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The FDA will decide by Thursday whether Juul’s devices and nicotine pods can stay on the market.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 6
item.description: Quote: “I feel like for me, recently, when I win, I don’t feel happy, I feel more like a relief. (The Verge)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: For the Defense Industry, 9/11 Changed Everything
item.description: Bottom line: US military spending as a share of GDP has shrunk since peaking in 2011, but the booming homeland security industry it helped create remains a permanent fixture of the economy. Before September 11, 2001, the US had been cutting military spending. Military spending doubled to $700 billion in the decade following 9/11, to about 20% of total government spending.   Did you know?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Weekend in Photos
item.description: John Walton/PA Images via Getty Images The Tokyo Paralympic Games closed this weekend with the US earning 37 gold medals, including in men’s wheelchair basketball and women’s sitting volleyball.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Winds Down Massive, Controversial Unemployment Benefits Program
item.description: The backstory: In March 2020, as the US was shedding almost 1 million jobs per day, Congress authorized an extra $600/week in unemployment benefits on top of what states offered to keep jobless Americans afloat (the $600/week was later reduced to $300 in August 2020).  In all, the US government has spent $680 billion on unemployment benefits since last March, the second-highest amount among Covid stimulus programs behind only the Paycheck Protection Program ($835 billion). Around the same time, the government also expanded the number of workers eligible for unemployment insurance (UI) by including people like gig workers and the self-employed.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: September 6
item.description: 9/11 anniversary: As we mentioned earlier, Saturday will mark 20 years since the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. Everything else: Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, begins this evening.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Winds Down Massive, Controversial Unemployment Benefits Program
item.description: The backstory: In March 2020, as the US was shedding almost 1 million jobs per day, Congress authorized an extra $600/week in unemployment benefits on top of what states offered to keep jobless Americans afloat (the $600/week was later reduced to $300 in August 2020).  In all, the US government has spent $680 billion on unemployment benefits since last March, the second-highest amount among Covid stimulus programs behind only the Paycheck Protection Program ($835 billion). Around the same time, the government also expanded the number of workers eligible for unemployment insurance (UI) by including people like gig workers and the self-employed.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: For the Defense Industry, 9/11 Changed Everything
item.description: Bottom line: US military spending as a share of GDP has shrunk since peaking in 2011, but the booming homeland security industry it helped create remains a permanent fixture of the economy. Before September 11, 2001, the US had been cutting military spending. Military spending doubled to $700 billion in the decade following 9/11, to about 20% of total government spending.

item.title: Musicals 'Waitress' and 'Hadestown' Return to Broadway
item.description: Big picture: Covid has been more damaging for the musical theater industry than Russell Crowe’s turn as Javert.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: (Wired) Then they got Tourette’s.  Read: They saw a YouTube video.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Apple's Crazy Week
item.description: Wednesday: Apple offered its second App Store concession in less than a week, allowing companies like Netflix and Spotify to direct users to payment methods outside of the App Store.  Yesterday: Apple said it would delay the rollout of its new software that scans devices for child sexual abuse content so it can make improvements.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Booster Vaccine Doses Turn Into a Three-Shot Circus
item.description: The backstory: President Biden announced that Americans who received Pfizer’s or Moderna’s vaccine could begin getting their third shots the week of Sept.  Big picture: The necessity of third shots is still dividing the scientific community. 20, as long as it had been at least eight months since they got their second shot.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Delta Crashes the Jobs Party
item.description: This jobs report whiff will reverberate around DC.   US employers added just 235,000 jobs last month, compared to the 720,000 expected. Hiring was expected to fall from the 1.1 million jobs added in July and 962,000 in June, but nowhere near this much. In total, there are 5.6 million fewer workers holding jobs in the US now than before the pandemic hit.  Leisure and hospitality, a sector that falters when Covid anxieties are higher, reported no job increases last month.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What Does it Mean if QR Codes Are Here to Stay?
item.description: So, given that QR codes are likely not a pandemic fad and will be distracting us in restaurants for years to come, what are the implications? And half of all full-service restaurants in the US have opted for QR code menus since the beginning of the pandemic, per the National Restaurant Association. The ease of creating a QR code is one of the reasons why it’s so accessible for businesses, but it also increases opportunities for fraud. While it might seem like you’re just harmlessly ordering a Denny’s Grand Slam® after a long day, QR codes track when, where, and how often you scan them. Looks like it’s 2011 again: the cool kids are dressing like they’re in Gossip Girl, everyone’s talking about a Kanye album, and QR codes are trying to make it big. The Better Business Bureau even issued a warning this summer around fraudulent QR codes.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Booster Vaccine Doses Turn Into a Three-Shot Circus
item.description: The backstory: President Biden announced that Americans who received Pfizer’s or Moderna’s vaccine could begin getting their third shots the week of Sept.    But in a meeting at the White House this week, federal health officials said those initial boosters might need to be limited to just those who got Pfizer’s vaccine, per reports.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Delta Crashes the Jobs Party
item.description: This jobs report whiff will reverberate around DC.   US employers added just 235,000 jobs last month, compared to the 720,000 expected. In total, there are 5.6 million fewer workers holding jobs in the US now than before the pandemic hit. Hiring was expected to fall from the 1.1 million jobs added in July and 962,000 in June, but nowhere near this much. It was averaging 350,000 new jobs a month over the past six months. Looking ahead...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers with...Master Sommelier Ian Cauble
item.description: But most people don't have that bottle of wine you found on that shelf in that specific wine shop. With just a 5% pass rate, the top wine test has snarled the dreams of all but 267 people who are able to call themselves a true Master. In 2012, Ian Cauble passed the wine world’s version of astronaut training to become one of only a few Master Sommeliers in the world. Why is wine the go-to dinner party gift? Most people start by working in restaurants for a very long time—a lot of them for more than 10 years by the time they pass the Master Sommelier exam. It’s a very easy gift and there's usually a great story behind it. I would say most wine is not designed to age.
item.author: Matty Merritt
